metadata.source: Charlie Munger's Latticework - Compiled from Poor Charlie's Almanack, Worldly Wisdom speeches, and personal documents

thinkers.name: Ray Dalio
key_works: Principles for Dealing with the Changing World Order

categories.name: Psychology: Tendencies & Biases
categories.description: Munger's 25 standard causes of human misjudgment plus extended biases

categories.name: Thinking Tools & Meta-Frameworks
categories.description: Methods for better reasoning and decision-making

categories.name: Business: Competitive Advantage & Moats
categories.description: Durable competitive advantages and market dynamics

mental_models.name: Reward and Punishment Superresponse Tendency
mental_models.description: People respond intensely to incentives, both positive and negative. Never think about something else when you should be thinking about incentives.

mental_models.name: Liking/Loving Tendency
mental_models.description: We tend to distort facts to favor people and things we like or love, ignoring faults and complying with wishes.

mental_models.name: Disliking/Hating Tendency
mental_models.description: We distort facts, ignore virtues, and dislike people associated with those we already dislike.

mental_models.name: Doubt-Avoidance Tendency
mental_models.description: The brain is designed to remove doubt by reaching quick decisions, especially under stress.

mental_models.name: Inconsistency-Avoidance Tendency
mental_models.description: We resist changing our habits, beliefs, and conclusions once formed. The brain conserves programming space.

mental_models.name: Curiosity Tendency
mental_models.description: Humans have a natural drive to seek knowledge and understanding, which can be cultivated.

mental_models.name: Kantian Fairness Tendency
mental_models.description: We expect fair exchanges and reciprocal behavior, and react strongly to perceived unfairness.

mental_models.name: Envy/Jealousy Tendency
mental_models.description: Envy drives much human behavior and is often underestimated as a motivating force.

mental_models.name: Reciprocation Tendency
mental_models.description: We feel obligated to repay favors and concessions, even when unsolicited.

mental_models.name: Influence-from-Mere-Association Tendency
mental_models.description: We are influenced by associations, both positive and negative, even when logically irrelevant.

mental_models.name: Simple, Pain-Avoiding Psychological Denial
mental_models.description: We deny reality when it is too painful to accept, distorting facts to reduce psychological pain.

mental_models.name: Excessive Self-Regard Tendency
mental_models.description: We overestimate our own abilities, contributions, and the value of what we own.

mental_models.name: Overoptimism Tendency
mental_models.description: We tend to be unrealistically optimistic about outcomes, especially our own.

mental_models.name: Deprival-Superreaction Tendency
mental_models.description: We react more intensely to losses than to equivalent gains. Loss aversion drives much behavior.

mental_models.name: Social-Proof Tendency
mental_models.description: We look to others to determine correct behavior, especially in uncertain situations.

mental_models.name: Contrast-Misreaction Tendency
mental_models.description: We misjudge based on contrasts rather than absolute values, leading to poor decisions.

mental_models.name: Stress-Influence Tendency
mental_models.description: Stress can cause both enhanced performance and dysfunction, including extreme reactions.

mental_models.name: Availability-Misweighing Tendency
mental_models.description: We overweight information that is easily available or vivid in memory.

mental_models.name: Use-It-or-Lose-It Tendency
mental_models.description: Skills and knowledge deteriorate without practice and use.

mental_models.name: Drug-Misinfluence Tendency
mental_models.description: Chemical substances can severely impair cognition and judgment.

mental_models.name: Senescence-Misinfluence Tendency
mental_models.description: Aging naturally degrades cognitive function, though continuous learning can slow decline.

mental_models.name: Authority-Misinfluence Tendency
mental_models.description: We tend to follow authority figures even when they are wrong or acting against our interests.

mental_models.name: Twaddle Tendency
mental_models.description: People spend time on trivial matters while ignoring important ones.

mental_models.name: Reason-Respecting Tendency
mental_models.description: People comply more readily when given reasons, even poor ones.

mental_models.name: Lollapalooza Effect
mental_models.description: When multiple psychological tendencies act in concert, they create extreme outcomes - the key to understanding major events.

mental_models.name: Confirmation Bias
mental_models.description: We seek information that confirms our existing beliefs and ignore contradictory evidence.

mental_models.name: Hindsight Bias
mental_models.description: We believe past events were predictable after learning the outcome.

mental_models.name: First-Conclusion Bias
mental_models.description: We tend to accept the first conclusion that comes to mind without adequate analysis.

mental_models.name: Anchoring Bias
mental_models.description: Initial information disproportionately influences subsequent judgments.

mental_models.name: Incentive-Caused Bias
mental_models.description: Professional incentives unconsciously bias judgment and recommendations.

mental_models.name: Pavlovian Association/Conditioning
mental_models.description: We form automatic associations through repeated pairing of stimuli.

mental_models.name: Hyperbolic Discounting/Short-Termism
mental_models.description: We overvalue immediate rewards relative to future ones.

mental_models.name: Representativeness Bias
mental_models.description: We judge probability by similarity to stereotypes rather than base rates.

mental_models.name: Status Quo Bias/Habit Persistence
mental_models.description: We prefer the current state of affairs and resist change.

mental_models.name: Inversion
mental_models.description: Invert, always invert. Solve problems backwards. Think about what you want to avoid.

mental_models.name: Checklist Approach
mental_models.description: Use systematic checklists to avoid omission errors and ensure comprehensive analysis.

mental_models.name: Two-Track Analysis
mental_models.description: Analyze problems through both rational factors and psychological/subconscious influences.

mental_models.name: Elementary Worldly Wisdom
mental_models.description: Build a latticework of basic models from multiple disciplines for better thinking.

mental_models.name: Latticework of Mental Models
mental_models.description: Facts must hang together on a latticework of theory to be useful.

mental_models.name: Multidisciplinary Approach
mental_models.description: Draw models from multiple disciplines - all wisdom is not in one academic department.

mental_models.name: Circle of Competence
mental_models.description: Know the boundaries of your knowledge and stay within them.

mental_models.name: First Principles Thinking
mental_models.description: Break down problems to fundamental truths and reason up from there.

mental_models.name: Second-Order Thinking
mental_models.description: Think beyond first effects to subsequent consequences.

mental_models.name: Occam's Razor
mental_models.description: Prefer simpler explanations over complex ones when equally valid.

mental_models.name: Hanlon's Razor
mental_models.description: Don't attribute to malice what can be explained by stupidity or incompetence.

mental_models.name: Falsification/Disconfirming Evidence
mental_models.description: Actively seek evidence that disproves your hypothesis, like Darwin did.

mental_models.name: Scenario Analysis
mental_models.description: Consider multiple possible futures and plan for various outcomes.

mental_models.name: Mental Accounting
mental_models.description: Understand how people psychologically frame and categorize money differently.

mental_models.name: Black Swan Events
mental_models.description: Prepare for extreme, hard-to-predict events with massive impact.

mental_models.name: Gray Rhino Events
mental_models.description: Recognize obvious but neglected big risks that people ignore.

mental_models.name: Vivification
mental_models.description: Make ideas vivid and concrete so they stick in memory.

mental_models.name: Man-with-a-Hammer Tendency
mental_models.description: Avoid overusing one model - to a man with a hammer, everything looks like a nail.

mental_models.name: Supply and Demand
mental_models.description: Prices are determined by the interaction of supply and demand.

mental_models.name: Elasticity
mental_models.description: Sensitivity of quantity demanded or supplied to changes in price or other factors.

mental_models.name: Opportunity Cost
mental_models.description: The true cost of anything is what you give up to get it.

mental_models.name: Comparative Advantage
mental_models.description: Specialize in what you do relatively better, even if not absolutely better.

mental_models.name: Marginal Utility/Diminishing Returns
mental_models.description: Each additional unit provides less satisfaction than the previous one.

mental_models.name: Time Value of Money
mental_models.description: Money today is worth more than the same amount in the future.

mental_models.name: Incentives & Incentive Alignment
mental_models.description: People respond to incentives - ensure they are properly aligned.

mental_models.name: Agency Problem/Principal-Agent Problem
mental_models.description: Agents may not act in the best interest of principals they represent.

mental_models.name: Information Asymmetry
mental_models.description: One party has more or better information than another in a transaction.

mental_models.name: Adverse Selection
mental_models.description: Bad participants drive out good ones when information is asymmetric.

mental_models.name: Moral Hazard
mental_models.description: Behavior changes when insulated from risk or consequences.

mental_models.name: Pareto Principle (80/20 Rule)
mental_models.description: Roughly 80% of effects come from 20% of causes.

mental_models.name: Gresham's Law
mental_models.description: Bad money drives out good; can apply broadly to quality degradation.

mental_models.name: Creative/Competitive Destruction
mental_models.description: Innovation destroys old industries while creating new ones.

mental_models.name: Value to a Private Owner
mental_models.description: What would a rational private buyer pay for the entire business?

mental_models.name: Mr. Market
mental_models.description: The market is a manic-depressive partner offering prices daily - use it, don't be used by it.

mental_models.name: Margin of Safety
mental_models.description: Buy with a significant buffer between price and value to protect against errors.

mental_models.name: Tax Deferral & Compounding Advantage
mental_models.description: Deferring taxes allows more capital to compound over time.

mental_models.name: Value Creation vs. Value Capture
mental_models.description: Creating value is different from capturing it - who keeps the surplus?

mental_models.name: Obsolescence Risk
mental_models.description: Business decay from innovation and changing technology.

mental_models.name: Economic Moats
mental_models.description: Durable competitive advantages that protect a business from competition.

mental_models.name: Cost Advantages
mental_models.description: Structural low-cost position that competitors cannot easily replicate.

mental_models.name: Differentiation & Brand Power
mental_models.description: Unique products or strong brands that command premium pricing.

mental_models.name: Switching Costs
mental_models.description: Costs that make it difficult for customers to change suppliers.

mental_models.name: Network Effects
mental_models.description: Value increases as more users join the network.

mental_models.name: Scale Economies - Supply Side
mental_models.description: Fixed costs spread over larger volumes reduce per-unit costs.

mental_models.name: Scale Economies - Demand Side
mental_models.description: More users create more value for all users.

mental_models.name: Learning/Experience Curve
mental_models.description: Costs fall with cumulative production as efficiency improves.

mental_models.name: Lock-In via Distribution/Physical Network
mental_models.description: Physical distribution networks create barriers to entry.

mental_models.name: Winner-Take-All/Winner-Take-Most Markets
mental_models.description: Markets where the leader captures disproportionate value.

mental_models.name: Moat Durability
mental_models.description: How long the competitive advantage will last.

mental_models.name: Industry Structure
mental_models.description: Monopoly, oligopoly, or competitive dynamics shape profitability.

mental_models.name: Rational vs. Cutthroat Competition
mental_models.description: Some industries compete rationally; others destroy value through price wars.

mental_models.name: Platform Economics
mental_models.description: Two-sided markets connecting different user groups.

mental_models.name: Capacity & Supply Discipline
mental_models.description: Overcapacity destroys returns; disciplined supply maintains pricing.

mental_models.name: Surfing Long Waves
mental_models.description: Riding strong secular trends for sustained growth.

mental_models.name: Technology as Friend vs. Killer
mental_models.description: Technology can strengthen or destroy competitive positions.

mental_models.name: Bureaucracy/Diseconomies of Scale
mental_models.description: Large organizations develop dysfunction that offsets scale benefits.

mental_models.name: Cancer-Surgery Formula
mental_models.description: Cut out bad parts quickly to save the system.

mental_models.name: Basic Arithmetic Fluency
mental_models.description: Master basic math - you must be able to handle numbers and quantities.

mental_models.name: Permutations & Combinations
mental_models.description: The elementary math of possibilities - essential for probability thinking.

mental_models.name: Expected Value
mental_models.description: Probability-weighted average of all possible outcomes.

mental_models.name: Probabilistic Thinking/Base Rates
mental_models.description: Think in probabilities, not certainties. Start with base rates.

mental_models.name: Bayes' Rule/Bayesian Updating
mental_models.description: Update probabilities as new evidence arrives.

mental_models.name: Regression to the Mean
mental_models.description: Extreme outcomes tend to be followed by more average ones.

mental_models.name: Normal Distribution vs. Fat Tails
mental_models.description: Many distributions have fatter tails than normal - extreme events more likely.

mental_models.name: Power Laws
mental_models.description: Extreme concentration of outcomes - a few items dominate.

mental_models.name: Cost-Benefit Analysis
mental_models.description: Formalized comparison of costs and benefits for decision-making.

mental_models.name: Compounding
mental_models.description: Growth on growth - the eighth wonder of the world.

mental_models.name: Optionality/Asymmetric Payoffs
mental_models.description: Positions with limited downside and unlimited upside.

mental_models.name: Kelly-Type Thinking
mental_models.description: Optimal position sizing based on edge and odds.

mental_models.name: Critical Mass
mental_models.description: Threshold where dynamics fundamentally change.

mental_models.name: Leverage
mental_models.description: Amplifying force or outcome through mechanical or financial means.

mental_models.name: Redundancy/Backup Systems
mental_models.description: Multiple systems ensure reliability when one fails.

mental_models.name: Breakpoints/Phase Transitions
mental_models.description: Points where systems shift to fundamentally different states.

mental_models.name: Friction & Efficiency Losses
mental_models.description: Real systems have friction that reduces efficiency.

mental_models.name: Reliability Engineering/Safety Margins
mental_models.description: Build in safety factors to handle unexpected stresses.

mental_models.name: Feedback Loops - Positive (Reinforcing)
mental_models.description: Self-reinforcing cycles that amplify changes.

mental_models.name: Feedback Loops - Negative (Stabilizing)
mental_models.description: Self-correcting cycles that maintain equilibrium.

mental_models.name: Bottlenecks & Constraints
mental_models.description: System output limited by the weakest link.

mental_models.name: Nonlinearity
mental_models.description: Disproportionate responses - small inputs can cause large outputs.

mental_models.name: System Resilience vs. Fragility
mental_models.description: Some systems strengthen under stress; others break.

mental_models.name: Evolution by Natural Selection
mental_models.description: Variation, selection, and retention drive adaptation.

mental_models.name: Adaptation & Fitness Landscapes
mental_models.description: Organisms and organizations adapt to their environment.

mental_models.name: Red Queen Effect
mental_models.description: Must run hard just to stay in place as competitors evolve.

mental_models.name: Niches & Ecological Competition
mental_models.description: Specialization in narrow niches can be highly successful.

mental_models.name: Population Dynamics
mental_models.description: Boom-bust cycles in populations and markets.

mental_models.name: Autopsy Learning
mental_models.description: Study failures and deaths to learn what went wrong.

mental_models.name: Corporate Governance
mental_models.description: Board incentives and oversight structures matter.

mental_models.name: Management Incentives & Compensation Design
mental_models.description: How managers are paid determines how they behave.

mental_models.name: Culture as a Control System
mental_models.description: Norms and culture are more powerful than formal rules.

mental_models.name: Bureaucratic Inertia & Empire Building
mental_models.description: Organizations naturally grow bureaucracy and resist change.

mental_models.name: Information Suppression/Shooting the Messenger
mental_models.description: Bad news gets filtered out as it moves up the hierarchy.

mental_models.name: Five W's Rule in Communication
mental_models.description: Always tell who, what, where, when, and especially WHY.

mental_models.name: Checklists & Standard Operating Procedures
mental_models.description: Systematic processes reduce errors and ensure consistency.

mental_models.name: Talent, Trust, and Delegation
mental_models.description: Few, high-quality people with trust and autonomy outperform bureaucracy.

mental_models.name: Avoiding Madness in Crowds
mental_models.description: Resist groupthink and maintain independent judgment.

musk_5_step_algorithm.description: Elon Musk's 5-Step Algorithm for optimizing any process

steps.name: Question Every Requirement
steps.description: Make requirements less dumb. The requirements are definitely dumb - it does not matter who gave them to you.

steps.name: Delete
steps.description: Delete the part or process. If you are not adding back at least 10% of what you delete, you are not deleting enough.

steps.name: Simplify/Optimize
steps.description: Simplify and optimize. The most common error is to optimize something that should not exist.

steps.name: Accelerate Cycle Time
steps.description: Speed up the cycle time. But only after you have done the first three steps.

steps.name: Automate
steps.description: Automate. This comes last because you do not want to automate something that should not exist.

soros_reflexivity.description: George Soros's theory of reflexivity - the two-way feedback between perception and reality
principles: Markets are always biased in one direction or another
Markets can influence the events they anticipate
The relationship between thinking and reality is reflexive
Equilibrium is the exception, not the rule

dalio_principles.description: Ray Dalio's core principles for decision-making
principles: Embrace reality and deal with it
Be radically open-minded and radically transparent
Understand that people are wired very differently
Learn how to make decisions effectively
